Fig. 1 Free energy diagrams on the Rh(111) surface at steady-state coverage at 423 K. The panel shows the pathways to (a) propionaldehyde and (b) methane. The species added at each step are labeled on the bottom axis. The free energies of the reactants (ethylene, CO, H2) were computed at a pressure of 1.0 MPa and at an ethylene/H2/CO ratio of 1:1:1. All other free energies were computed for the standard state. Fig. 2 Volcano plots showing the theoretical activities for the production of (a, c) propionaldehyde and (b, d) ethane from CO and H2 without (a, b) and with (c, d) the inclusion of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. The TOFs for the (111) surfaces are plotted as functions of the CHO and CH binding energies, as obtained by the microkinetic model. The reaction temperature was set at 423 K. The CH and CHO binding energies represent the formation energies of the adsorbed species relative to the CO, H2, and H2O gas-phase energies. Fig. 3 Consumption rates of ethylene (right axis) and selectivity toward propionaldehyde (left axis) on Rh(111) plotted on a log scale vs. temperature. (a) Without adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. (b) With adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. Fig. 4 High-throughput screening of Rh-based catalysts with two descriptors (i.e., the CH and CHO binding energies). (a) Selectivity toward propionaldehyde for Rh-based catalysts as a function of the CH and CHO binding energies under identical conditions to those presented in Fig. 2. Both black and white circles represent models for which only the CH and CHO binding energies were evaluated: black circles correspond to single-atom-substituted models, and white circles to ordered alloy models. Research article Rational design of selective catalysts for ethylene hydroformylation via microkinetic modeling and universal neural network potentials Kento Sakai Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Software Methodology Investigation Formal analysis a ⁎ Ippei Furikado Writing – review & editing Supervision a Andrew J. Medford Writing – review & editing Supervision b a Analytical Science Research Laboratories, Kao Corporation, 1334, Minato, Wakayama-shi, Wakayama 640-8580, Japan Analytical Science Research Laboratories Kao Corporation 1334, Minato Wakayama-shi Wakayama 640-8580 Japan Analytical Science Research Laboratories, Kao Corporation, 1334, Minato, Wakayama-shi, Wakayama 640-8580, Japan b School of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, 30332, USA School of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering Georgia Institute of Technology Atlanta GA 30332 USA School of Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering, Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, GA, USA ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Rapid prediction of the activity and selectivity of catalysts is essential for advancing catalyst development. Computational chemistry offers a promising approach for achieving this aim by enabling such predictions without experimentation. However, traditional methods, such as density functional theory calculations, can be computationally expensive. In this study, we report a descriptor-based microkinetic model that describes the selectivity and activity trends in ethylene hydroformylation on close-packed metal facets using a universal neural network potential. By incorporating adsorbate–adsorbate interactions, our model successfully reproduced the experimental trends in both catalyst activity and selectivity, including the higher production rates of propionaldehyde for Rh and Ir. Furthermore, a high-throughput screening approach was used to evaluate the efficacy of various Rh-based candidates, providing insights into potential improvements through the addition of secondary components. Overall, this study highlights the potential of integrating neural network potentials with microkinetic modeling to advance the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts. Keywords Hydroformylation Heterogeneous catalysis Descriptor-based microkinetic modeling Universal neural network potential Rational catalyst design Adsorbate–adsorbate interaction 1 Introduction Catalysts have played a crucial role in numerous industrial processes over the past century, and their significance continues to increase due to their ability to address various environmental challenges, such as global warming, renewable energy, and marine pollution [1–3]. Despite their growing significance, the development of new catalysts still relies largely on trial-and-error, similar to the work performed in the early 20th century [4]. This time-consuming and costly approach highlights the need for alternative strategies to accelerate catalyst development. To address this issue, the computational screening of catalysts with increased activity and selectivity has gained significant attention during the past few decades [5–7]. This interest has been driven by advancements in computational chemistry, particularly in terms of the density functional theory (DFT) approach, which enables the prediction of catalytic performance in both homogeneous and heterogeneous systems [5–8]. In the modeling of heterogeneous catalysis, the gold standard is a multiscale model, which combines the energetics of elementary steps in the reaction mechanism with mean-field microkinetic modeling or kinetic Monte Carlo simulations [9]. However, constructing a kinetic model often requires numerous calculations related to the adsorbed and transition states, resulting in high computational costs. Moreover, recent studies have emphasized the necessity of including adsorbate–adsorbate interactions in some kinetic models [10,11], which further increases computational costs. Consequently, several machine learning-based approaches have been proposed to reduce the computational costs associated with DFT calculations [12–14]. In particular, neural network potentials (NNPs) combined with large-scale datasets have rapidly gained attention [15–17]. The PreFerred potential (PFP) packaged in MatlantisTM is one of the most promising potentials, offering approximations comparable to those of DFT, but at a significantly faster speed [18]. PFP learns from the results generated by the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional [19], and supports a total of 72 elements. Hydroformylation is a crucial chemical process, producing over 10 million tons of aldehydes annually [20]. This process, which uses olefins and syngas (CO/H2) as reactants, is 100% atom efficient. The desired oxygenates (e.g., hydroxycitronellal [21]) are valuable chemicals in the field of fine chemistry, such as in the fragrance and pharmaceutical industries [22,23]. Furthermore, it has been reported that the use of a mixture of CO2 and H2 as a syngas surrogate in this reaction can contribute to the generation of carbon-neutral systems [24]. Homogeneous catalysts are widely used in industry owing to their high activity and selectivity [25], wherein electronic and steric effects are known to significantly affect the catalytic performance [26]. However, the separation of homogeneous catalysts from the reaction solution presents various challenges, such as metal leaching and waste discharge [27]. Consequently, the development of heterogeneous hydroformylation catalysts that can be readily separated has attracted considerable attention over the last decade. The key issue associated with heterogeneous catalysts is their low selectivity for oxygenates, which is attributed to the hydrogenation and isomerization of alkenes via side reactions. To date, various Rh-based heterogeneous catalysts have been studied owing to their higher activity compared to other metal-based systems [28,29]. In addition, it has been found that the use of promoters, such as Co [30], Mo [31], V [32], W [33], and alkali metals, can lead to an enhanced catalyst selectivity [34]. Single-atom catalysts, which are known for their high efficiency and the uniform electronic states of their active metals, have also been extensively studied [35]. However, the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts remains elusive, highlighting the requirement for a deeper understanding of selectivity patterns across different metals and their surfaces. Previously, hydroformylation on the Rh(111) surface has been studied using DFT calculations [30,36], with CO insertion being identified as the rate-determining step. Although descriptor-based microkinetic modeling, which relies on energies obtained from DFT calculations, is a promising approach for predicting trends in catalysts selectivity and rates [37–39], it has not yet been applied to hydroformylation. According to previous reports, under heterogeneous catalytic reaction conditions involving CO as a reactant, such as in syngas conversion, the surface coverage of CO typically reaches around 0.5 monolayers (ML) [40]. In such cases, unlike in homogeneous catalysis [41], it becomes necessary to consider lateral adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. Several studies have already highlighted the importance of incorporating these effects into microkinetic modeling [11,42–46]. Hydroformylation involves both CO and H2 as reactants, and thus such interactions are also expected to play a significant role. Thus, in the current study the potential of high-throughput catalyst screening is explored using a combination of NNPs and microkinetic modeling, focusing on the hydroformylation of ethylene as a model reaction. For this purpose, PFP is used to calculate the energies and transition states on the face-centered cubic (111) facets of Au, Ag, Cu, Pt, Pd, Ir, Rh, and Ni, and on the hexagonal close-packed (0001) facets of Os and Ru. Additionally, microkinetic modeling is performed both in the presence and absence of lateral adsorbate–adsorbate interactions, and the results are compared with those of previous reports. Using the constructed microkinetic model, a range of Rh-based catalysts are evaluated through high-throughput screening. It is proposed that this study will hold significant implications for the design and optimization of heterogeneous hydroformylation systems. 2 Methods 2.1 Computational details Calculations were performed using the PFP version 6.0.0 on MatlantisTM [18]. We adopted a potential trained on data that did not include the Hubbard U correction. Geometry optimizations were initially carried out using the Fast Inertial Relaxation Engine (FIRE) method [47], followed by optimizations using the Limited-memory Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (LBFGS) algorithm [48] with a force threshold of 0.005 eV Å−1. During all calculations, the atoms in the bottom layer were fixed. The adsorbed structures were optimized using Optuna version 3.5.0 [49]. The lowest-energy structure was selected from configurations sampled using the Tree-structured Parzen Estimator algorithm, in which the center-of-mass coordinates and Euler angles—defining the orientation of the adsorbates—were used as optimization variables. The transition state geometries were calculated using the climbing image nudged elastic band method [50]. The vibrational frequencies were computed using a finite difference approximation of the Hessian matrix and subsequent diagonalization to determine the normal modes, as implemented in the Atomic Simulation Environment (ASE, version 3.22.1) [51]. The vibrational frequencies were used to compute the free energies of the adsorbates by assuming that all degrees of freedom were harmonic vibrational modes. The vibrational frequencies of the adsorbed species that were determined to be < 12 cm−1 were set to 12 cm−1 to approximate the entropic contribution from the pseudotranslational/rotational degrees of freedom [52]. The gas-phase energies were computed using PFP, and free-energy corrections of the gas-phase species were performed using the IdealGasThermo class implemented in the ASE. The conformational space of each gas-phase species was searched using the ETKDGv2 algorithm [53] implemented in RDKit [54]. The maximum number of generated conformers per tautomer was set to 100. The atomic structures, energies, and metadata were stored in the ASE database SQLite3 files, which are provided as Supporting Information (SI). Additional DFT calculations were performed using the Quantum ESPRESSO plane-wave code [55] with the PBE functional [19]. All other parameters are outlined in Section 1 of the SI. 2.2 Microkinetic modeling Microkinetic modeling was performed using the “Catalysis Microkinetic Analysis Package” (CatMAP) software package (version 0.3.1) [37]. Site coverage was modeled using the mean-field approach and by steady-state approximations. The surface was modeled using two surface sites, namely a “hydrogen reservoir” site [39] and a site for all other intermediates. We assumed that hydrogen did not compete with any of the other adsorbates for the adsorption sites, as is common in hydrogenation studies [11,46,56]. We adopted the following reaction mechanism proposed in previous studies [36]: (i) C2H4* is hydrogenated to generate C2H5*, (ii) CO* inserts into the adsorbed C2H5*, and (iii) C2H5CO* is hydrogenated to generate C2H5CHO*. In a sub-reaction, C2H4* is hydrogenated via the adsorbed C2H5* to generate C2H6, wherein * indicates the adsorbed state. To widen the applicability of the developed model, we added the pathways for CH4 formation, also following the reaction mechanism suggested in the literature [39], i.e., the C–O bond splits in the CHOH* intermediate, and the CH* adsorbate is further hydrogenated to yield CH4. All elementary reactions are outlined in Table S1. In the proposed model, the adsorbate–adsorbate effects attributed to the co-adsorbed CO species on the Rh(111) surface are specifically included. Based on the strong adsorption of CO on Rh, CO* is expected to be the most abundant surface intermediate; thus, the current model includes all interactions between the surface intermediates and CO*. The CO* cross-interaction parameters were determined by calculating the adsorption energies of the intermediates at a high degree of coverage. Additionally, self-interactions were included for the C2H4*, C2H5CHO*, C2H5CO*, C2H5*, CH2*, CH3*, CHOH*, CHO*, CH*, OH*, and CO* adsorbates. For the fitting procedure, the integral adsorption energies calculated using PFP were employed. As the functional, a second-order adsorbate–adsorbate interaction model was used, which incorporated second-order expansion in the coverage to express the integral adsorption energy [11]. The model is given by: (1) E i n t θ i = ∑ i E i 0 θ i + 1 2 ∑ s ∑ q f sq 2 ∑ i ∈ s ∑ j ∈ q ε ij θ i θ j where E i 0 is the low-coverage limit of the differential heat of adsorption, θ i is the surface coverage of species i, s and q are indices of different types of adsorption sites, f sq is a piecewise linear function for the energy as a function of coverage on sites s and q, and εij is a matrix of interaction parameters for the interactions between species i and j. The differential adsorption energy (Ek ) can be derived as shown in Eq. (2): (2) E k = ∂ E i n t θ i ∂ θ k = E k 0 + ∑ s f s q k 2 ∑ i ∈ s ε ik θ i + 2 ∑ s f s q k f ′ s q k ∑ i ∈ s ∑ j ∈ q ε ij θ i θ j The microkinetic model was solved by initially converging the solution without interactions, and then incrementally increasing the interaction strength by 0.01. Minor modifications were performed to the CatMAP code to enable this, and the necessary patches are included in the SI. In the model, the turnover frequency (TOF) represents the net rate of change for a chemical species, where a positive value indicates net production, and a negative value indicates net consumption. The consumption rate is then defined as the absolute value of the TOF when it is negative. The propionaldehyde selectivity (S C2H5CHO) was defined using Eq. (3): (3) S C 2 H 5 C H O = T O F C 2 H 5 C H O T O F C 2 H 5 C H O + T O F C 2 H 6 + T O F C H 4 + T O F H 2 O Identical reaction pressure conditions were employed for the substrates and products, namely p C2H4 = p CO = p H2 = 0.33 MPa, and p C2H5CHO = p C2H6 = p CH4 = p H2O = 1.0 × 10−9 MPa. To determine the reaction rate at any point on the rate map generated by CatMAP, the following procedure was employed. When two descriptor energies were provided, the sampling point closest to these input values on the rate map was located. Subsequently, the LinearNDInterpolator of SciPy [57] was applied in the logarithmic space to interpolate around this point. The resulting interpolated value was then taken as the reaction rate. 2.3 Construction of alloy surface models using the Metropolis Monte Carlo method The Metropolis Monte Carlo (MMC) simulation [58] was used to obtain the alloy surface structures of the Rh-based slab models. In the MMC simulation, all atoms in the slab model were allowed to exchange with neighboring atoms. The cell parameters of the alloy models (as defined from optimization of the bulk lattice constant with PFP) were fixed. Geometry optimizations with PFP were initially performed using the FIRE method, followed by further optimizations using the LBFGS algorithm with a force threshold of 0.005 eV/Å. New structures were generated by exchanging two different types of atoms with their nearest neighbors. A newly generated structure after relaxation is accepted if E 1 < E 0 or if (4) r < e x p E 0 - E 1 kT where E 0 and E 1 are the total energies of the new and previous structures, respectively, and r is a random number between 0 and 1. The MMC simulations were stopped after 10,000 steps when the total energy no longer decreased substantially. The temperature used for the MMC simulations was 423 K, so the acceptance probability defined in Eq. (4) was evaluated at this temperature, guaranteeing that configurational states are Boltzmann-weighted appropriately. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Reaction paths for hydroformylation on the Rh(111) surface As part of earlier investigations, a comparison was made between the activation energies computed using a previous version of PFP and those calculated using the current DFT method [18]. To evaluate the accuracy of PFP version 6.0.0 used in this study, we compared the activation and adsorption energies calculated by PFP with those computed using DFT (PBE functional) [18,59]. The corresponding results are shown in Fig. S1 and Tables S2 and S3. All atomic structures used for the calculations are also provided in the SI. It was found that the reasonable mean absolute error (MAE) of the potential obtained using PFP version 6.0.0 was 0.14 eV. Using PFP, the free energy diagrams calculated for propionaldehyde, ethane, and methane on the Rh(111) surface under low CO coverage at 423 K and 1.0 MPa are shown in Fig. 1 . The free energy of CO adsorption at 423 K was determined to be −1.53 eV, indicating high coverage of CO under realistic reaction conditions. CO insertion exhibited the highest activation energy, aligning with previously reported results [36]. Methane was generated via the hydrogenation of CH*, which is also consistent with previous studies. In addition, the activation energy was reported to reach its highest value upon the hydrogenation of CO to form CHO [11]. The energy diagram calculated according to the DFT results is shown in Fig. S2, while the formation energies calculated using the DFT approach are listed in Table S7. The MAE of the formation energies was determined to be 0.014 eV. Based on these results, it was apparent that PFP energies are useful descriptors of DFT energies and can be used to construct PFP-based microkinetic models, as discussed in the following section. 3.2 Construction of the microkinetic model Several studies have reported that the calculated formation energies of adsorbates and transition states on heterogeneous metal surfaces are linearly correlated with one another [39]. In this study, the CatMAP linear scaler was used for the heterogeneous close-packed metal facets, and the calculation results obtained herein for the metals showed a comparable trend (Fig. S3). Thus, to construct the microkinetic model, these trends were employed to reduce dimensionality, and two descriptors (i.e., the energies of CHO* and CH*) were defined as design parameters for the selective and active catalytic sites. These descriptors were incorporated into a linear model to regress all remaining energies in the kinetic model, including the energies of the transition states. The MAE of the scaling relationship was determined to be 0.12 eV. The results obtained for the microkinetic model in the absence of interactions are shown in Fig. 2 (a) and 2(b). While Cu and Au showed the highest TOFs for propionaldehyde and ethane, the selectivity and TOF of propionaldehyde were low for other transition metals, such as Rh, Ir, and Co. Experimentally, it has been reported that Rh is generally more active than other metals [28], which is inconsistent with the current calculations. At this point, the CO coverage across the transition metals exceeds 0.99 (Fig. S4), indicating that the results do not reflect realistic reaction conditions. Previous experimental results for the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis using CO feed indicate that a CO coverage of ∼ 0.5 ML is near saturation at 493 K [41]. To address this issue, it is necessary to incorporate lateral interactions to reduce the adsorption energy and coverage. Thus, the microkinetic modeling of such lateral interactions was implemented using the fitting operations available in CatMAP. The fitting operations required high-adsorbate-coverage geometries, which were optimized using Optuna. Although the DFT approach has previously been used to predict the coverage-dependent adsorption of some adsorbates on metal surfaces [56], no reports have used NNPs to examine the effects of coverage on the adsorption energies. Thus, in the current study, the coverage-dependent adsorption energies of CO on Rh(111) were calculated, including both the adsorption energy per CO molecule and the total binding energy of the system. As shown in Fig. S5, the results obtained herein are generally consistent with previously reported DFT calculations [60]. The MAEs for the adsorption energy per CO molecule and for the total binding energy were determined to be 0.051 and 0.47 eV, respectively. Additionally, self-interaction coefficients were determined for all intermediates. To complement this, interactions with other co-adsorbed species were also considered. Given the strong adsorption of CO* on Rh, CO* was expected to be the most abundant surface intermediate. Therefore, calculations were performed at high coverages to incorporate interactions with the most abundant surface intermediate, CO. The developed model includes all interactions between surface intermediates and co-adsorbed CO*, evaluated at CO coverages selectively chosen from 0.44, 0.50, and 0.57 ML. As shown by the red circles in Fig. S6, the differential energies of intermediates and transition states increase with coverage, remaining relatively constant below 0.3 ML and increasing linearly above this threshold. A piecewise linear model was used to capture this behavior, as shown by the solid black line in Fig. S6. To ensure reliable fitting, we employed modified coverage definitions based on the number of carbon atoms in each molecule. This adjustment was necessary because applying a uniform coverage definition to one-, two-, and three-carbon species tends to underestimate the coverage and interactions for multi-carbon species. In the current work, the energy and coverage used for fitting for the adsorbate–adsorbate interaction model were determined based on different definitions depending on the number of carbon atoms in the molecule. For molecules with one or fewer carbon atoms, the coverage was calculated using the definition of “number of molecules per number of surface sites.” For molecules with two or more carbon atoms, coverage was defined as the “(number of molecules × 2) per number of surface sites.” For example, at θ = 0.125, the CO energy was based on a structure in which two CO molecules were adsorbed on 16 surface atoms, whereas for ethylene, the energy was taken from a structure wherein a single molecule was adsorbed on 16 surface atoms. It should be noted that, in both the fitting procedure and the microkinetic calculations, all molecules were assumed to occupy a single adsorption site. The values of each parameter are provided in Table S5. The results of the microkinetic model in the presence of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions are shown in Fig. 2(c) and 2(d). The maximum rates for propionaldehyde and ethane production were observed for Rh and Ir, consistent with experimental results [28]. By incorporating adsorbate–adsorbate interactions, the CO coverage on Rh was reduced to ∼ 0.8 ML (Fig. S7). The activity sequence for propionaldehyde was Rh > Ir > Ru > Os > Pd > Ni > Pt > Co > Au > Cu > Ag, whereas its selectivity sequence followed the order Rh > Ir > Pd > Ru > Os > Ni > Pt > Co > Au > Cu > Ag. The activities for CH4 and H2O generation were lower than those for aldehyde and ethane formation (Fig. S8); thus, considering that the formation of CH4 and H2O has rarely been observed in previous studies, this is considered to be a reasonable result. Temperature-dependence of TOF and selectivity both in the presence and absence of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions were subsequently performed, as shown in Fig. 3 . More specifically, Fig. 3(a) shows the dependence of ethylene hydroformylation on the reaction temperature in the absence of adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. Previous studies have demonstrated that the ethylene conversion increases with an increasing reaction temperature, whereas the selectivity toward oxygenate compounds decreases [31,32]. However, in the absence of these interactions, the current calculations did not align with these trends. In contrast, when the interaction parameters were included, the consumption of ethylene increased with an increase in temperature, as shown in Fig. 3(b), whereas the selectivity toward aldehyde formation decreased, consistent with the experimental results. In addition, the calculated TOF for propionaldehyde formation on Rh(111) was determined to be 15 h−1, which is the same order as the typical TOF range of 101 to 103 observed under temperatures of 373–473 K [28]. The current calculations therefore successfully reproduced some experimental trends and highlighted the necessity of including the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. Although the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions are not completely captured by piecewise linear functions, the developed model is relatively accurate in the regions of interest and represents a solid first step toward more comprehensive modeling, such as kinetic Monte Carlo simulations. Subsequently, the obtained volcano plots were evaluated in detail. In these plots, the horizontal axis represents the formation energy of CH (generated from the dissociation of CO), with a higher CH value indicating weaker CO adsorption. Since CHO exhibits a high affinity toward oxygen and its generation is related to the adsorption of both C2H5CO and propionaldehyde, the existence of a volcanic relationship between CH and CHO is plausible. The anomalously sharp change in the TOF for propionaldehyde toward the strong binding sides of the volcano plots, as shown in Fig. 2(c) and 2(d), results from the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions. Experimentally, changes in CO adsorption energy have been observed through temperature-programmed desorption or FTIR measurements. It has been discussed that increasing CO adsorption energy (i.e., making it less negative, thus weakening CO adsorption) improves activity and selectivity [30,36,61]. Importantly, the influence of Rh–O affinity extends beyond the modulation of CO adsorption energy. In systems such as Rh–MoOx [31] and Rh–VOx [32], strong Rh–O interactions have been shown to facilitate H2 activation and promote selective hydrogenation steps even under CO-rich conditions. These findings indicate that oxygen affinity directly contributes to the control of hydrogen-related pathways and overall reaction selectivity. Therefore, to fully understand the catalyst’s performance, it is essential to consider not only the interaction with CO, but also the broader affinity of Rh toward the support oxygen. This trend is not limited to heterogeneous systems. In homogeneous catalysis, a similar trend in catalytic activity has been reported, with the activity sequence being Rh ≫ Co > Ir > Ru > Os > Pt > Pd ≫ Fe > Ni. According to Sabatier's principle [62], Group 9 metals are more active in such systems, achieving an optimal balance in both types of catalysis due to the fact that the intermediates are neither too strongly nor too weakly bound. This suggests a fundamental correlation between homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts. The obtained computational results therefore indicate that weakening of the CH bond and strengthening of the CHO bond are essential steps for enhancing the aldehyde selectivity. Based on previous reports discussing the addition of oxide species, such as W [33], V [32], and Mo [31], it was considered that the incorporation of a secondary oxide component could also achieve an enhanced aldehyde selectivity, as described below. 3.3 High-throughput screening of Rh-based catalysts With the two-dimensional microkinetic model in hand, screening was performed using Rh as the representative metal. Among the 72 elements currently available for use in PFP version 6.0.0, H, C, N, O, halogens, noble gases, alkali metals, and alkaline earth metals were excluded. Ordered alloys were constructed using the remaining 51 elements. The optimal compositions for MxRhy were determined to be 1:3, 1:1, and 3:1 (for x:y). The constructed ordered alloys were selected based on the most stable structures obtained after performing MMC simulations. In addition, for elements including alkali and alkaline earth metals, the binding energies of CHO and CH were calculated using structures with a single-atom-substituted model, in which one atom on the Rh(111) surface was replaced by a second-component. These models were also constructed using MMC simulations, and all atomic structures are provided in the SI. Fig. 4 (a) outlines the calculated propionaldehyde selectivity, wherein the black circles represent the single-atom-substituted model and the white circles represent the ordered alloy models. Structures with CHO and CH binding energies outside the range calculated in Fig. 2 were excluded. In the single-atom-substituted model, the elements that exhibited an increased selectivity, in order of highest to lowest selectivity, were Nb, S, Ta, Te, Ni, Tc, Re, Os, Fe, Ru, Co, V, P, W, and Cr. Among these, several elements commonly exist as oxides under real conditions, and as predicted, the incorporation of a second component with a high adsorption energy toward oxygen atoms increased the selectivity. In these models, the adsorption of CH remained stable only on Rh, and the CH adsorption energy remained unchanged. Conversely, Rh crystal lattice modification, as observed in the ordered alloy models, suggested a further improvement in the selectivity. More specifically, enhanced selectivity was observed for the following alloy models, given in order from highest to lowest selectivity: Si3Rh1, Al3Rh1, B1Rh3, Mn1Rh3, Fe2Rh2, Al1Rh3, Re1Rh3, Ru1Rh3, Ir2Rh2, and Si2Rh2. A total of 20 elements across both the single-atom-substituted and ordered alloy models were evaluated, and approximately half (11 elements) have been previously reported to promote enhanced selectivity, including V [32], W [33], Co [36], Fe [63], Re [64], Mn [65], Al [66], B [67], Ru [68], P [69], and S [70]. Si typically exists in the form of SiO2 under reaction conditions. For instance, SiO2 is commonly used as a catalyst support, and Rh supported on zeolites—one form of SiO2—has been reported to exhibit > 99 % selectivity [71]. In contrast, Ni [30] was experimentally found to exhibit reduced selectivity. In the calculations, Ni with a single-atom-substituted model exhibited high selectivity, whereas Ni in the alloy model showed poor selectivity. This result suggests that the Ni structure reported in the previous study [30] may resemble that of the alloy model. Consequently, further tuning the structural environment of Rh and Ni could potentially lead to an improvement in selectivity. Several elements exhibited a higher selectivity toward propionaldehyde than Rh metal, including Ir, Nb, Ta, Te, Tc, Os, and Cr, which have not been previously reported in this context. To further reduce the candidate space, the price of elements was taken into consideration as shown in Table S6, and finally, Nb, Ta, and Te were identified as promising candidates. 3.4 Perspectives and outlook The present ethylene hydroformylation study demonstrates that NNPs coupled with microkinetic modeling can reproduce experimental trends while reducing the computational cost. The approach can be extended to propylene and even longer-chain substrates: a recent PFP investigation of hydrocarbon polymers [72] shows that the same NNP remains accurate for systems containing tens to hundreds of carbon atoms, indicating that reactions such as the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis, involving long hydrocarbons, can be modeled with NNPs. However, solvent is typically used in reactions with long hydrocarbons, and further development is required to consider solvent effects. For C3+ olefins, predicting regioselectivity (linear vs. branched) will become essential; the present work can in principle deliver such selectivity predictions, although selectivity predictions are generally much more sensitive to the accuracy of adsorption and transition state energies, and separating electronic-ligand effects from ensemble (site-blocking) effects will require additional electronic-structure analysis that lies beyond the scope of this study. Our MMC simulation includes only configurational entropy through the Boltzmann acceptance factor, with vibrational and electronic free-energy terms approximated by their 0 K values. Despite this approach, PFP-based MC simulation has already reproduced the Cu–Au order–disorder transition temperature [18]. Repeating the calculation with temperature-dependent vibrational terms provides a practical way to assess the effect of synthesis or calcination conditions. In fact, the MC studies that incorporate phonon-derived vibrational free energies into the Metropolis acceptance consistently lower the predicted transition temperature for metallic alloys such as Fe–Cr [73]. Building on these procedures, we will improve our MC simulation by appending quasi-harmonic corrections to the 0 K energies before sampling. Because PFP can generate accurate phonon spectra orders of magnitude faster than conventional DFT, the added cost of including vibrational terms is negligible. The recent Li7La3Zr2O12 study [74] further illustrates that NNPs can supply such corrections rapidly while decisively shifting finite-temperature phase stability. 4 Conclusion In this study, the effectiveness of combining neural network potentials and microkinetic modeling to predict and optimize catalytic performance in ethylene hydroformylation reactions was demonstrated. The developed computational approach, which was validated against experimental data, confirmed that Rh and Ir exhibited higher activity and selectivity in the production of propionaldehyde. Incorporating adsorbate–adsorbate interactions into the model proved essential to accurately predicting the catalytic behavior under realistic conditions. Additionally, the high-throughput screening of Rh-based alloys revealed several promising candidates for enhanced catalytic performance, aligning with reported trends and introducing new avenues for catalyst enhancement. Although certain secondary oxide components, such as Mo, V, and W, have been previously reported to significantly enhance the selectivity and activities of heterogeneous catalysts, a number of candidates were identified, including Ir, Nb, Ta, Te, Tc, Os, and Cr, to offer valuable insights for future experimental validation and application. Overall, this study advances our understanding of hydroformylation catalysis and highlights the broad applicability of integrating advanced computational methods for rational catalyst design. However, fine-tuning of the adsorbate–adsorbate interactions remains a challenge that requires further exploration, and which will be examined in future work. coredata.dc:description: Rapid prediction of the activity and selectivity of catalysts is essential for advancing catalyst development. Computational chemistry offers a promising approach for achieving this aim by enabling such predictions without experimentation. However, traditional methods, such as density functional theory calculations, can be computationally expensive. In this study, we report a descriptor-based microkinetic model that describes the selectivity and activity trends in ethylene hydroformylation on close-packed metal facets using a universal neural network potential. By incorporating adsorbate–adsorbate interactions, our model successfully reproduced the experimental trends in both catalyst activity and selectivity, including the higher production rates of propionaldehyde for Rh and Ir. Furthermore, a high-throughput screening approach was used to evaluate the efficacy of various Rh-based candidates, providing insights into potential improvements through the addition of secondary components. Overall, this study highlights the potential of integrating neural network potentials with microkinetic modeling to advance the rational design of heterogeneous catalysts.
